Data.event_text: Figures show the annual number of migrants crossing the English Channel fell during 2023, doing so for the first time since records began. The provisional annual total for 2023 is 29,437, a 36% decrease from the 2022 total of 45,774.

links.text: -Collins, Lauren (1 January 2024). "Channel migrants: Crossings fell in 2023, government figures show". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 1 January 2024.-

links.text: -Gribben, Paul; Gardner, Frank (1 January 2024). "Red Sea: UK defence secretary says British forces will repel Houthi attacks". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 1 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: VAT on period pants is abolished, potentially making the products cheaper to buy.

links.text: -Hooker, Lucy (1 January 2024). "Period pants could get cheaper after VAT is removed". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 1 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: Sir Keir Starmer admits he worries about the toll of a general election year on his two teenage children as he and his wife try to keep them out of the public eye.

Data.event_text: Ofgem grants permission for energy companies to resume the forced installation of prepayment meters a year after the practice was suspended and after drawing up new rules that prohibits them being installed under certain conditions, such as households where the occupant is over 75, where there are children under two, and for those with certain health conditions.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (8 January 2024). "Energy firms allowed to restart force-fitting meters". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: At an event held in Parliament Square, the actor Idris Elba calls on the UK government to introduce an immediate ban on the sale of zombie knives and machetes to reduce the number of young people losing their lives because of the weapons.

Data.event_text: London and the south-east see a mix of snow, sleet, and rain as the country braces for a week-long cold spell.

Data.event_text: More than a million people have signed a petition calling for former Post Office chief executive Paula Vennells to be stripped of her CBE in the wake of the Horizon IT scandal.

Data.event_text: Economists say that funding the student loans system in England is expected to cost the government an extra £10 billion a year.

Data.event_text: Baroness Heather Hallett, chair of the UK COVID-19 Inquiry, confirms the inquiry will postpone the start of hearing evidence about the development of a vaccine as more time is needed to prepare for a separate investigation into the impact of COVID-19 on the NHS. Consequently, the vaccine evidence, which was due to begin being heard in Summer 2024 may not begin until after the next general election.

links.text: -Reed, Jim (10 January 2024). "Covid inquiry postpones vaccine investigation". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 10 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: An Opposition day House of Commons debate calling for a ceasefire in Gaza descends into chaos after Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle breaks with Parliamentary convention to allow a vote on a Labour amendment calling for an "immediate humanitarian ceasefire" over the scheduled SNP motion calling for an "immediate ceasefire". The decision leads to protests from both Conservative and SNP MPs, who walk out of the House, leaving Labour's motion to be nodded through when the other two parties do not take part in the vote. Data.event_text: Forty-five protesters are arrested after obstructing a coach moving asylum seekers in Peckham to the Bibby Stockholm.

links.text: -"Bibby Stockholm: 45 arrests as protesters block coach in bid to stop asylum seekers being moved to barge". BBC News. 2 May 2024. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: John Swinney is set to become the next SNP leader and first minister after Kate Forbes confirms she will not seek the party's leadership.

links.text: -"Swinney looks set to be first minister as Forbes backs him". BBC News. 2 May 2024. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Goldman Sachs becomes the first firm to remove the cap on bankers' bonuses following the 2023 change in UK law regarding bonuses.

links.text: -King, Ben (2 May 2024). "Goldman Sachs removes bankers' bonus limit". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts that the UK will have the slowest economic growth among the world's developed nations during 2025.

links.text: -"UK growth set to be slowest of richest nations in 2025, says OECD". BBC News. BBC. 2 May 2024. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: A man is remanded in custody charged with the murder of Daniel Anjorin, as well as two counts of attempted murder.

links.text: -Low, Harry; Manning, Lucy (2 May 2024). "Daniel Anjorin: Marcus Monzo in court over death of schoolboy in Hainault". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: King Charles III is presented with his Coronation scroll, the first to be made without the use of animal skin.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (2 May 2024). "King's official Coronation scroll is first without animal skin". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 2 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: With 90% of council election results announced, the Conservatives have lost over 400 council seats, while Labour regains control of Hartlepool, Redditch, Rushmoor and Thurrock Councils.
Ben Houchen wins the Tees Valley mayoral election, retaining the seat for the Conservatives, while Labour win mayoral elections in the East Midlands, North East and York and North Yorkshire.
Chris Webb wins the 2024 Blackpool South by-election, with a 26% swing to Labour.
Research carried out by the University of Leicester suggests squirrels may have passed leprosy on to mediaeval humans in the UK.

links.text: -Price, Nia (3 May 2024). "Squirrels may have given medieval Britons leprosy". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 3 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 2024 London mayoral election Labour's Sadiq Khan secures a third term as Mayor of London with 44% of the vote, beating the Conservative Susan Hall on 33%.

links.text: -"Sadiq Khan wins third term as London mayor". BBC News. BBC. 4 May 2024. Retrieved 4 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 2024 West Midlands mayoral election Labour's Richard Parker narrowly defeats the Conservative incumbent Andy Street to become Mayor of the West Midlands.

links.text: -Murray, Jessica (4 May 2024). "Labour's Richard Parker beats Andy Street to become West Midlands mayor". The Guardian. Retrieved 4 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 2024 Greater Manchester mayoral election Labour's Andy Burnham secures a third term as Mayor of Greater Manchester with almost two-thirds of the votes cast.

links.text: -Burnell, Paul; Horsburgh, Lynette (4 May 2024). "Andy Burnham wins third term as mayor of Greater Manchester". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 4 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 5 May  With all votes counted, the results from the local elections in England are Labour 1,158 (+186), Liberal Democrat 522 (+104), Conservative 515 (−474), Independents and others 228 (+93), Green 181 (+74), Residents' Association 48 (+11), Workers Party of Britain 4 (+4), Reform UK 2 (+2).

links.text: -"Local election results 2024". BBC News. BBC. 5 May 2024. Retrieved 5 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: King Charles III, celebrates the first anniversary of his coronation.

links.text: -"King Charles celebrates coronation anniversary with highlights video". The Times. 6 May 2024. Retrieved 6 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The NHS will roll out laser interstitial thermal therapy (known as LITT) next month in England to help reduce seizures for patients with epilepsy that cannot be controlled by standard anti-seizure drugs.

links.text: -"Epilepsy patients to be offered 'game-changing' laser therapy in NHS rollout". The i Paper. 6 May 2024. Retrieved 6 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: John Swinney is confirmed as Leader of the Scottish National Party after being unopposed in the leadership election, and begins his second tenure in the post.

links.text: -Cochrane, Angus (6 May 2024). "John Swinney wins SNP leadership unopposed". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 6 May 2024.-

links.text: -da Silva, João; Jordan, Dearbail (6 May 2024). "Heineken £39m investment to reopen more than 60 closed UK pubs". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 6 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Kyren Wilson wins the 2024 World Snooker Championship, defeating Jak Jones 18 frames to 14.

links.text: -Sutcliffe, Steve (6 May 2024). "World Championship: Kyren Wilson beats Jak Jones to win world title". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 6 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Farmers call for a vaccine to be developed against bluetongue disease after 126 cases are reported in cattle and sheep, spread by infected midges blown from northern Europe.

links.text: -"Bluetongue farm virus warning for sheep and cattle as midges blown into UK". BBC News. BBC. 7 May 2024. Retrieved 7 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: China is suspected of hacking the UK armed forces payroll.

links.text: -"MoD data breach: China suspected of hacking UK armed forces payroll". BBC News. BBC. 7 May 2024. Retrieved 7 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Green Party's Siân Berry, who was re-elected in the 2024 London Assembly election, is criticised for resigning three days later to hand her seat to Zoë Garbett, who lost in the same election with 5.8% of the vote. Berry steps down from the post in order to run as Green candidate in Brighton Pavilion, where current MP Caroline Lucas is standing down at the next election.

links.text: -"Fury as Green Party member quits London Assembly just three days after being elected". The Independent. 7 May 2024. Retrieved 7 May 2024.-
-Vickers, Noah (8 May 2024). "Siân Berry: Green London Assembly member quits days after election". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 May 2024.-

links.text: -Mitchell, Jenness (8 May 2024). "Scottish First Minister John Swinney unveils cabinet as Kate Forbes becomes deputy". Sky News. Retrieved 8 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Natalie Elphicke, MP for Dover, defects from the Conservatives to Labour as Prime Minister's Questions begins in the Commons, saying in a statement "Under Rishi Sunak, the Conservatives have become a byword for incompetence and division."

Data.event_text: Former cricketer Monty Panesar of the Workers Party, withdraws his candidacy to stand for election as the next MP for Ealing Southall in the 2024 general election as he needs more time to "mature and find my political feet".

Data.event_text: The Bank of England keeps interest rates on hold at 5.25% for the sixth time in a row. The governor Andrew Bailey says the committee needs to "see more evidence" of falling inflation before cutting the base rate.

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that legislation will be brought forward to ban sex offenders in England and Wales from changing their names to avoid detection.

Data.event_text: The UK economy is reported to have moved out of recession, with 0.6% growth between January and March, the fastest rate for two years.

links.text: -"UK exits recession with fastest growth in two years". BBC News. BBC. 10 May 2024. Retrieved 10 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 75-year-old Piran Ditta Khan is sentenced to life imprisonment, with a minimum term of 40 years, for the shooting dead of police officer Sharon Beshenivsky during an armed robbery in 2005.

links.text: -"Sharon Beshenivsky: Life term for ringleader's part in PC's murder". BBC News. BBC. 10 May 2024. Retrieved 10 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Two elderly women from climate protest group Just Stop Oil target Magna Carta in the British Library, attempting to smash its glass container with a hammer and chisel. The documents themselves are undamaged.

links.text: -"Just Stop Oil protesters in their 80s target Magna Carta". Sky News. 10 May 2024. Retrieved 10 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Liberty, a device that allows cancer patients to take some blood tests at home and upload the data, is given approval for use at 12 cancer treatment sites within the NHS.

Data.event_text: The Co-op Live arena says it is ready to open after completing safety checks, with Elbow scheduled to perform as the opening act on 14 May.

links.text: -Youngs, Ian (10 May 2024). "Co-op Live arena says Elbow will play opening gig after inspection". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 11 May 2024.-

links.text: -Panons, Jacob (11 May 2024). "UK records hottest day of the year so far". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 11 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Foreign Secretary David Cameron tells the BBC's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg that a ban on the sale of UK weapons to Israel would only strengthen Hamas.

links.text: -Francis, Sam (12 May 2024). "UK ban on selling arms to Israel would strengthen Hamas, says Cameron". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 May 2024.-

links.text: -"Prince William flies Apache helicopter at handover ceremony". BBC News. BBC. 13 May 2024. Retrieved 13 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: At a campaign event in Essex, Labour leader Keir Starmer outlines the first steps his party will take if they win the next general election. These are economic stability, a cut in NHS waiting times in England, a new Border Security Command, the establishment of Great British Energy, a crackdown on antisocial behaviour in England, and 6,500 more teachers in England.

links.text: -Mason, Chris; Francis, Sam (17 May 2024). "Keir Starmer sets out what Labour would do first if it wins election". BBC News. Retrieved 18 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The BBC reports that HPV vaccinations in young people are now so successful that cervical cancer "could be eradicated in the near future."

links.text: -"HPV vaccine stops 90% of cervical cancer cases". BBC News. BBC. 16 May 2024. Retrieved 16 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Moroccan asylum seeker Ahmed Alid is sentenced to life imprisonment, with a minimum term of 45 years, for the murder of 70-year-old Terence Carney in Hartlepool. Mrs Justice Cheema-Grubb tells Alid "The murder of Terence Carney was a terrorist act in which you hoped to influence the British government. You hoped to frighten the British people and undermine the freedoms they enjoy."

Data.event_text: Declassified documents clear the Welsh Guards of any responsibility in the Argentinian Air Force bombing of RFA Sir Galahad on 8 , leading to the biggest loss of British lives during the Falklands War; some had blamed the Welsh Guards for disobeying orders to leave the ship, where 48 crewmen were killed.

Data.event_text: The results of a public inquiry into the contaminated blood scandal are published. The report accuses doctors, the government, and the NHS of trying to cover-up mistakes, which led to over 3,000 deaths and 30,000 infections of hepatitis C and HIV, described by inquiry chair Sir Brian Langstaff as "a calamity."

links.text: -"Infected blood scandal victims betrayed by cover up, inquiry says". BBC News. BBC. 20 May 2024. Retrieved 20 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: The High Court grants permission to WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to appeal against his extradition order to the US over the alleged leaking of military secrets.

links.text: -"Assange wins right to challenge US extradition". BBC News. BBC. 20 May 2024. Retrieved 20 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: Conservative MP Anthony Mangnall, whose constituency covers Brixham, calls for customers of South West Water to receive compensation they "deserve", following the recent outbreak of cryptosporidium.

links.text: -"MP calls for water parasite outbreak compensation". BBC News. BBC. 20 May 2024. Retrieved 20 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: In the Commons, Paymaster General John Glen lays out details of the compensation scheme for victims of the infected blood scandal, which is estimated to cost £10bn.

links.text: -"Minister setting out multi-billion pound infected blood compensation". BBC News. BBC. 21 May 2024. Retrieved 21 May 2024.-

Data.event_text: 28 September  Labour MP Rosie Duffield quits the party over what she describes as leader Keir Starmer's "cruel" policies and "staggering hypocrisy" over his acceptance of gifts. In her resignation letter to Starmer she says, "The sleaze, nepotism and apparent avarice are off the scale. I am so ashamed of what you and your inner circle have done to tarnish and humiliate our once proud party." Her resignation is the fastest by an MP following a general election in modern political history.

links.text: -"MP Rosie Duffield quits Labour over Starmer 'hypocrisy'". BBC News. BBC. 28 September 2024. Retrieved 28 September 2024.-

links.text: -Relph, Daniela; Coughlan, Sean (18 October 2024). "King and Queen greeted by light show on Australia tour". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 18 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The body of Scotland's former first minister, Alex Salmond, is flown back to Scotland from North Macedonia in a private jet paid for by Scottish businessman Tom Hunter.

links.text: -"Body of Scottish independence champion Alex Salmond flown home from North Macedonia". AP News. 18 October 2024. Retrieved 18 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office warns of strong winds, potentially reaching 80 mph, along with heavy rain, ahead of the expected arrival of Storm Ashley.

links.text: -"Storm Ashley Named". Met Office. 18 October 2024. Retrieved 18 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: 647 migrants cross the English Channel.
BBC News reports that the UK government is exploring how to hand over ownership of the Post Office to thousands of subpostmasters.

links.text: -Owen, Meghan; Davies, Maia (19 October 2024). "Ministers explore handing Post Office ownership to sub-postmasters". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: In a Sunday Times interview, Olympic cyclist Sir Chris Hoy says that he has been told by doctors he has terminal cancer.

links.text: -"Cyclist Chris Hoy announces that his cancer is terminal". BBC News. BBC. 19 October 2024. Retrieved 19 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces plans to appoint a minister to oversee the building of HS2, as well as confirming it will not reinstate the route's Birmingham to Manchester leg.

links.text: -Edwards, Charlotte (20 October 2024). "HS2: Ministers to oversee build as costs 'spiral'". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 20 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: An amber weather alert is in place for western Scotland and the north and west of Northern Ireland as Storm Ashley arrives in the UK; yellow alerts are issued for other parts of Scotland, Northern Ireland and the Welsh coast.

links.text: -"Storm Ashley: Amber warning as 'weather bomb' hits Scotland". BBC News. BBC. 18 October 2024. Retrieved 20 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Metropolitan Police officer Martyn Blake is cleared of the murder of Chris Kaba, who was shot in Streatham in September 2022.

links.text: -Jackson, Liz; Britton, Jeremy; Campbell, Adina (21 October 2024). "Chris Kaba shooting: Police officer not guilty of murder". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 21 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: BBC News reports that the Serious Fraud Office is investigating the construction of a hotel and conference centre owned by the Unite union.

links.text: -Pike, Joe (21 October 2024). "Serious Fraud Office probe £112m Unite union hotel". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 21 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces plans to make more medical records, test results and letters from doctors available on the NHS App.

links.text: -Triggle, Nick (21 October 2024). "Patients to get full access to record on NHS App". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 21 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: A man dies and 15 people treated in hospital following a low-speed crash between two trains near the village of Llanbrynmair in Powys.

links.text: -Duggan, Craig; Matthews, Antonia (21 October 2024). "Man dies, 15 injured, after two trains collide". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Reporting restrictions are lifted on the background of Chris Kaba, who it is revealed was a suspect in a shooting at a nightclub days before his death, and was also a rapper who belonged to the infamous 67 gang, a UK drill group and criminal gang.

links.text: -Campbell, Adina; Nagesh, Ashitha (22 October 2024). "Chris Kaba shot man in nightclub days before his death". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Figures show that government borrowing rose by £16.6bn in September 2024, the third highest September on record since records began in 1993.

links.text: -Labiak, Mitchell (22 October 2024). "UK borrowing for September rises ahead of Budget". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The International Monetary Fund increases its growth forecast for the UK from 0.7% (in July) to 1.1%, and says the UK economy is set to "accelerate".

links.text: -Islam, Faisal (22 October 2024). "Reeves welcomes IMF's improved growth forecast". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government begins a second tranche of early prisoner releases involving 1,100 inmates in order to alleviate prison overcrowding in England and Wales.

links.text: -Kotecha, Sima; Casciani, Dominic (22 October 2024). "More prisoners freed early to ease overcrowding". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) announces that the Alzheimer's drug Donanemab will not be made available on the NHS in England because of its cost and relatively minor benefit to patients.

links.text: -Gallagher, James; Roxby, Philippa (23 October 2024). "Donanemab: NHS will not fund new drug to slow Alzheimer's". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Two survivors of the Manchester Arena bombing win a High Court case against former television producer Richard Hall, who had alleged that the terrorist attack was staged.

links.text: -Mullen, Tom; Gawne, Ewan; Spring, Marianna (23 October 2024). "Manchester Arena bomb survivors win conspiracy harassment case". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Charles III and Camilla arrive in Samoa for a state visit, where the King will preside over the 2024 Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

links.text: -Watson, Katy (23 October 2024). "King Charles and Queen Camilla arrive in Samoa to red carpet welcome". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Yvette Cooper announces that firearms officers facing trial over shooting suspects will have automatic anonymity until conviction under new reforms.

links.text: -Howard, Jacqueline; Comerford, Ruth (23 October 2024). "Firearms officers to get anonymity in shooting legal proceedings – Cooper". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: A woman is arrested on suspicion of manslaughter following the deaths of three residents at a care home in Swanage, Dorset.

links.text: -Stafford, Stephen; Cridland, Sophie; Pascoe, Tristan (23 October 2024). "Swanage care home: Woman arrested following three deaths". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: French authorities say 3 people died after a small boat carrying 48 migrants got into trouble attempting to cross the Channel from France to England. This brings the death toll for 2024, so far, to 56. In 2023 there were 12 deaths.
It is confirmed that the sale of disposable vapes will be banned in England and Wales from June 2025.

links.text: -Cooney, Christy; Walker, Amy (24 October 2024). "Disposable vapes to be banned from June". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 24 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Convicted killer Lucy Letby's bid to appeal against her latest conviction for the attempted murder of a baby girl is dismissed by the Court of Appeal.

links.text: -"Lucy Letby loses bid to appeal against conviction". BBC News. BBC. 24 October 2024. Retrieved 24 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor Rachel Reeves announces the UK government is to change its self-imposed debt rules in order to make an extra £50bn available for spending at the forthcoming budget.

links.text: -Islam, Faisal; Espiner, Tom (24 October 2024). "Rachel Reeves: Chancellor changes debt rules to release billions". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 24 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Alexander McCartney, 26, who organised one of the largest catfishing operations on the Internet, is sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 20 years. His crimes, which targeted around 3,500 children across 30 countries, are described by Mr Justice O'Hara as ones of "sadism and depravity" which "scarred" the childhoods of his victims.

links.text: -"Abuser in 'UK's largest catfishing case' jailed for life over girl's manslaughter". BBC News. BBC. 25 October 2024. Retrieved 25 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Appearing at the Old Bailey, Dylan Earl pleads guilty to carrying out an arson attack on a Ukrainian-owned business in east London on behalf of Russia.

links.text: -Sandford, Daniel (25 October 2024). "Man admits arson over London warehouse fire linked to Russia". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 25 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: A Scottish couple are given permission to proceed with a legal case that will attempt to overturn the scrapping of universal winter fuel payments for pensioners.

links.text: -"Couple given go-ahead to sue governments over winter fuel payment". BBC News. BBC. 25 October 2024. Retrieved 25 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: 27 October  Labour MP Mike Amesbury is suspended from the party and has the whip withdrawn, after CCTV footage emerges appearing to show him punching a man to the ground.

links.text: -"Labour suspends MP after CCTV appears to show him punching man". BBC News. BBC. 27 October 2024. Retrieved 27 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Far-right activist Tommy Robinson is sentenced to 18 months in prison for contempt of court for repeating false allegations against a Syrian refugee, in breach of an injunction.

links.text: -"Tommy Robinson jailed for contempt of court". BBC News. BBC. 28 October 2024. Retrieved 28 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: Manchester United sack manager Erik ten Hag less than 24 hours after a 21 defeat to West Ham United, leaving the club in 14th place after nine games. Assistant Ruud van Nistelrooy takes charge on an interim basis until a permanent replacement is found.

links.text: -"Club statement: Erik ten Hag". Manchester United F.C. 28 October 2024. Retrieved 4 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: United Kingdom budget Rachel Reeves unveils her first budget as Chancellor, which includes £40bn in tax rises, intended to offset what she alleges is a £22bn "black hole" in the nation's finances, while enabling the largest hike in NHS funding since 2010.

links.text: -"This is not a Budget we want to repeat, says Reeves". BBC News. 30 October 2024. Retrieved 31 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The first case of Clade Ib mpox, a more spreadable variant linked to the outbreak in Africa, is detected in the UK.

links.text: -"First case of more spreadable mpox detected in UK". BBC News. 30 October 2024. Retrieved 31 October 2024.-
-"UKHSA detects first case of Clade Ib mpox". Gov.uk. 30 October 2024. Retrieved 31 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Independent Schools Council, which represents around 1,400 private schools in the UK, votes to take legal action against government plans to end their tax exemption status from January 2025.

links.text: -McGough, Kate; Clarke, Vanessa (31 October 2024). "Private schools proceed with legal action over VAT plans". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 1 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: GB News is fined £100,000 by Ofcom for breaking impartiality rules with a programme featuring the former Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

links.text: -"Ofcom fines GB News £100,000 over impartiality". BBC News. 31 October 2024. Retrieved 31 October 2024.-

Data.event_text: 1 November  Sporting's Ruben Amorim is announced as Manchester United's new head coach. He will take charge on 11 November.

links.text: -"Man Utd appoint Ruben Amorim as new head coach". Manchester United F.C. 1 November 2024. Retrieved 4 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Kemi Badenoch wins the Conservative leadership election, defeating rival Robert Jenrick after securing the support of party members.

links.text: -"Kemi Badenoch wins Conservative Party leadership contest". BBC News. 2 November 2024. Retrieved 2 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: A joint investigation carried out by Channel 4's Dispatches and The Sunday Times reveals the extent of rent received by the Royal Estate from schools, the National Health Service and the armed forces.

links.text: -McNamee, Michael Sheils (2 November 2024). "Royal estates 'receive millions from public bodies and charities'". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 2 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: An elderly British couple, reported missing in Spain's recent flash flooding, are found dead in their car.

links.text: -"British couple missing in Spain floods found dead". BBC News. 4 November 2024. Retrieved 4 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson announces that university tuition fees in England, fixed at £9,250 a year since 2017, will be increased from 2025.

links.text: -"University tuition fees in England expected to rise for first time in eight years". BBC News. 4 November 2024. Retrieved 4 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Two more cases of Clade 1b mpox are identified in the UK, in household contacts of the first patient.

links.text: -"Two new cases of more spreadable mpox found in UK". BBC News. 4 November 2024. Retrieved 5 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Buckingham Palace announces that Queen Camilla has cancelled a number of scheduled engagements due to a chest infection.

links.text: -"Queen Camilla withdraws from engagements due to chest infection". BBC News. BBC. 5 November 2024. Retrieved 5 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Health Secretary Wes Streeting announces that the NHS will review its policy on testing for prostate cancer following Sir Chris Hoy's "powerful" call for younger men to get tested.

links.text: -Roberts, Michelle (5 November 2024). "Sir Chris Hoy: NHS to review prostate cancer testing after cyclist calls for change". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 5 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that the Tobacco and Vapes Bill will include plans to ban smoking outside schools and hospitals in England, but will not extend the ban to beer gardens as had been previously proposed.

links.text: -Roxby, Philippa (5 November 2024). "Pub garden smoking ban no longer in government plans". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 5 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Figures published by the British Retail Consortium indicate a 0.6% growth in retail sales during October, a figure lower than September, and attributed to the later October half term and people waiting for Black Friday deals.

links.text: -Partington, Richard (5 November 2024). "UK retail sales growth slumps as shoppers wait for Black Friday deals". The Guardian. Retrieved 6 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Briton Callum Tindal-Draper is killed while fighting with the 4th International Legion in Ukraine.

links.text: -Thorpe, George; Danks, John (9 November 2024). "Ukraine: Cornish family pay tribute to son killed in action". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 9 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: 6 November  At Newcastle Crown Court, former GP Thomas Kwan is sentenced to 31 years in prison after posing as a community nurse to inject his mother's partner with a substance that caused him to contract a flesh eating disease following a row over inheritance.

links.text: -Leatherdale, Duncan (6 November 2024). "Sunderland GP jailed for poisoning mum's partner over inheritance". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 6 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England cuts the UK interest rate by 0.25% to 4.75%, but indicates further cuts may take longer than previously thought following the October budget, which it forecasts will lead to price increases.

links.text: -Jordan, Dearbail; Islam, Faisal (7 November 2024). "UK interest rates cut to 4.75% but Bank hints fewer falls to come". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 7 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Argentinian authorities announce that three people have been charged in connection with the death of One Direction's Liam Payne.

links.text: -Rhoden-Paul, André (7 November 2024). "Liam Payne: Three charged in connection with singer's death". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 7 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: A report into more than 100 allegations of sexual abuse against barrister John Smyth QC, who died in 2018, finds his activities were covered up by the Church of England for several decades. Smyth used his home as a Christian summer camp during the 1970s and 1980s, when the abuse of boys and young men is thought to have happened.

links.text: -McArthur, Tom (7 November 2024). "John Smyth QC: Decades of abuse covered up by church, report says". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Football Association opens a safeguarding inquiry into a Premiership club official following sexual allegations made by three women.

links.text: -Price, Hannah (7 November 2024). "FA to investigate Premier League club boss over alleged sexual offences". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The charity organisation Care England estimates that as a result of the increase in employers' National Insurance contributions and the national minimum wage in the recent budget, that the cost of providing care will increase by over £3,000 per person and that the increases are expected to be passed on to care home residents and their relatives.

links.text: -Ivens, Fran (7 November 2024). "Care home fees to soar £3,000 a year under Labour". The Telegraph.-

Data.event_text: MP for Runcorn and Helsby, Mike Amesbury, is to be charged with common assault, following a police investigation into video footage that appeared to show him punching a man to the ground in the street. Amesbury was suspended from the Labour Party after the video emerged.

links.text: -Gawne, Ewan; Lazaro, Rachael (7 November 2024). "MP Mike Amesbury charged with assault in street". BBC News.-

Data.event_text: Following the election of Donald Trump as the president of the US, the foreign secretary, David Lammy, when asked if had changed his mind over his previous description of Trump as a "tyrant" and "a woman-hating, neo-Nazi-sympathising sociopath", chose not to answer that question, instead saying that was "old news".

links.text: -Mason, Chris; Morton, Becky (7 November 2024). "Lammy dismisses past criticism of Trump as 'old news'". BBC News.-

Data.event_text: Buckingham Palace confirms that the Princess of Wales will attend Remembrance events alongside the King and Prince of Wales.

links.text: -Comerford, Ruth; Coughlan, Sean (8 November 2024). "Princess of Wales to attend Remembrance events". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Competition and Markets Authority recommends overturning a ban on baby milk price promotions to stop parents "paying over the odds" for formula.

links.text: -Labiak, Mitchell (8 November 2024). "Baby milk discount ban should be lifted, watchdog says". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The death certificate of Susan McGowan, a 58-year-old nurse from North Lanarkshire who died in September, has linked her death with the use of the weight loss drug tirzepatide (known under the brand name Mounjaro), which was recently approved for use on the NHS; it is reported to be the first UK death linked to the drug's use.

links.text: -MacPhee, Catriona; Cheyne, James (8 November 2024). "Nurse's death linked to weight-loss drug Mounjaro approved on NHS". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Harrods boss Michael Ward apologises over the Mohamed Al-Fayed sexual abuse allegations after being approached by journalists from the BBC.

links.text: -Masud, Faarea; Graham, Darin; Price, Ellie (8 November 2024). "Harrods boss Michael Ward 'dreadfully sorry' for Al Fayed abuse". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Conspiracy theorist and former television producer Richard Hall is ordered to pay £45,000 in compensation to two victims of the Manchester Arena bombing after alleging the attack was staged.

links.text: -Gill, Andy; Sherlock, Gemma (8 November 2024). "Manchester Arena attack conspiracist ordered to pay £45k in damages". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 9 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: 9 November  Buckingham Palace announces that Queen Camilla will miss Remembrance events held over the weekend as she recovers from a chest infection.

links.text: -"Queen to miss Remembrance events after chest infection". BBC News. BBC. 9 November 2024. Retrieved 9 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: 10 November  First Minister of Northern Ireland Michelle O'Neill becomes the first senior Sinn Féin figure to take part in an official Remembrance Sunday ceremony, held in Belfast.

links.text: -"Remembrance Sunday: Michelle O'Neill first senior Sinn Féin figure to attend ceremony". BBC News. BBC. 10 November 2024. Retrieved 10 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life) Bill, which would allow terminally ill people in England and Wales with less than six months to live to seek assistance in ending their lives, with the consent of two doctors and a High Court judge, is published.

links.text: -Young, Vicky; Morton, Becky (11 November 2024). "Assisted dying bill has strict safeguards, MP Kim Leadbeater says". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 11 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Helen-Ann Hartley, the Bishop of Newcastle, calls for Justin Welby to resign as the Archbishop of Canterbury following a damning report into prolific child abuser John Smyth QC, who was associated with the Church of England.

links.text: -Maqbool, Aleem; Davies, Maia (11 November 2024). "Archbishop of Canterbury: Bishop urges Justin Welby to resign amid Church abuse scandal". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: At the Old Bailey, former soldier Daniel Khalife changes his plea midway through his trial, and pleads guilty to escaping from prison in September 2023. His trial on three other charges continues.

links.text: -Sandford, Daniel (11 November 2024). "Daniel Khalife changes plea to guilty on prison escape charge". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: At the invitation of French President Emmanuel Macron, Starmer travels to France to mark Armistice Day at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, then holds talks with Macron to affirm the UK and France's commitment to supporting Ukraine.

links.text: -Francis, Sam (11 November 2024). "Macron and Starmer commit to Ukraine for 'as long as necessary'". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The BBC confirms that Gary Lineker will step down as Match of the Day presenter at the end of the current season, but will host BBC Sport's coverage of the 2026 World Cup.

links.text: -"Lineker to stop hosting Match of the Day, BBC confirms". BBC News. BBC. 12 November 2024. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, announces his resignation following a review of his handling of historical allegations of abuse in the church by the barrister John Smyth QC.

links.text: -Aikman, Ian (12 November 2024). "'Best interests of the Church': Justin Welby resigns over abuse scandal". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The NHS is to start offering Varenicline, a daily pill to help people stop smoking.

links.text: -Roberts, Michelle (12 November 2024). "NHS offers 'improved' stop-smoking pill varenicline". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: A man is arrested in Westminster after reports of someone carrying a knife outside the Houses of Parliament.

links.text: -"Westminster: Man arrested over knife incident outside Parliament". BBC News. BBC. 12 November 2024. Retrieved 12 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Samantha Harvey wins the Booker Prize for her novel Orbital.

links.text: -Rufo, Yasmin (12 November 2024). "Booker Prize 2024: British author Samantha Harvey wins with Orbital". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 16 November 2024.-

links.text: -Gerken, Tom; Razzall, Katie (13 November 2024). "The Guardian stops posting on Elon Musk's 'toxic' X". BBC News.-

Data.event_text: DIY retailer Homebase collapses into administration, threatening 2,000 jobs.

links.text: -Espiner, Tom (13 November 2024). "Homebase collapses with 2,000 jobs at risk". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 13 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Statistics have revealed that a 26-year-old man from Wales is one of around 50 motorists still allowed to drive, despite exceeding the 30 penalty point limit, having accrued 229 penalty points.

links.text: -Aitken, Catriona (13 November 2024). "Flintshire driver with 229 points still holds valid licence". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 13 November 2024.-

links.text: -Francis, Sam (13 November 2024). "Assisted dying law would hit other NHS services, Wes Streeting warns". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 13 November 2024.-

links.text: -Roberts, Michelle (13 November 2024). "NHS managers to be sacked in failing hospitals – Streeting". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 13 November 2024.-

links.text: -"Reeves in radical pension shake-up to boost growth". BBC News. BBC. 14 November 2024. Retrieved 14 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Three women who were employees of Harrods allege that they were sexually abused by Mohamed Al-Fayed's brother, Salah between 1989 and 1997.

links.text: -Davies, Olivia; Adnitt, Jo; Price, Hannah (14 November 2024). "Mohamed Al Fayed's brother Salah also abused Harrods staff, women say". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 14 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: It is announced that folic acid will be added to non-wholemeal wheat flour in the UK to help prevent birth defects.

links.text: -Roberts, Michelle (14 November 2024). "Folic acid to be added to flour to help stop birth defects". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 14 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Office for National Statistics indicates the UK economy grew by 0.1% in the third quarter of 2024, down from 0.5% in the second quarter. The decrease is attributed to uncertainty over Labour's first budget and continued high interest rates.

Data.event_text: Myles McHugh, a serving Metropolitan Police officer, is dismissed for gross misconduct after having viewed confidential files related to the murder of Sarah Everard without good cause. A tribunal also finds Hannah Rebbeck and Mark Harper guilty of gross misconduct for the same reason. Rebbeck, who has already left the police, would have been dismissed if she were still serving, while Harper is given a final written warning.

links.text: -"Met Police officer sacked for accessing Sarah Everard files". BBC News. 15 November 2024. Retrieved 15 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office issues a weather warning for snow and ice for southern Scotland and northern England, beginning on 17 November.

links.text: -Fawkes, Chris (14 November 2024). "UK snow and ice warnings issued as Arctic air sweeps in". BBC Weather. BBC. Retrieved 15 November 2024.-

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (15 November 2024). "Mortgage rates rise despite interest rate cut". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 16 November 2024.-

links.text: -"UK snow and ice warnings as weather turns colder". BBC News. BBC. 16 November 2024. Retrieved 16 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Several thousand people attend a protest in London over inheritance tax increases for farmers, announced in the October budget.

Data.event_text: In a letter to Chancellor Rachel Reeves, a group of the UK's high street retailers has warned the "cumulative burden" of tax rises announced in the October budget, as well as other policies already in the pipeline, will add billions in costs to the retail sector and put jobs at risk.

Data.event_text: The UK government estimates that 50,000 pensioners will be living in poverty in 2025 as a result of cuts to winter fuel payments.

links.text: -Whannel, Kate (19 November 2024). "Winter fuel cut to put 50,000 pensioners into relative poverty". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: Inflation rises from 1.7% to 2.3%, its highest level in six months, driven by rising energy costs.

links.text: -Race, Michael; Masud, Faarea (20 November 2024). "Rising energy bills push inflation to highest for six months". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 20 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: A Briton, 28-year-old Simone White, is among those reported to have died in a mass poisoning in Laos.

links.text: -"British lawyer is fifth person to die in suspected methanol poisoning in Laos". The Guardian. 21 November 2024. Retrieved 21 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: A report by the Charity Commission into activities at the Captain Sir Tom Moore Foundation finds that Hannah and Colin Ingram-Moore (Moore's daughter and son-in-law) benefited from their association with the charity, including money from a £1.4m book deal paid to a family company, not to the Foundation.

links.text: -Pike, Joe; Rhoden-Paul, André (21 November 2024). "'I was shocked' by Captain Tom charity, says ex-boss". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 21 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces it will overhaul what it describes as the "feudal" leasehold system in England and Wales by the end of the current parliament.

-Media, P. A. (20 November 2024). "Three men arrested after bomb squad called to bus station in Glasgow". The Guardian. ISSN 0261-3077. Retrieved 22 November 2024.-

Data.event_text: The former prime minister, Boris Johnson, accuses Starmer of misleading the House of Commons and says he should correct the record immediately. This follows an exchange in the House during PMQs when Starmer, answering a question from the leader of the opposition, Kemi Badenoch, said that "two of her predecessors had convictions for breaking the Covid rules". Although the former Conservative prime ministers, Johnson and Rishi Sunak had received fixed penalty notices for breaking COVID-19 regulations, neither had any criminal convictions.

links.text: -"Tories call on Starmer to correct record over partygate 'conviction' claim". Independent. PA. 4 December 2024.-

links.text: -"Kate joined by children as she hosts carol service". BBC News. 5 December 2024. Retrieved 7 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Storm Darragh Hundreds of thousands are left without power, while travel is disrupted and many planned events are called off, as winds of up to 93 mph (150 km/h) hit much of the UK, along with heavy rain. A rare red weather warning is in place in Wales and south-west England, meaning the storm poses a risk to life. The deaths of two men are reported, in Birmingham and Lancashire, due to trees falling on vehicles.

links.text: -"Thousands left without power and travel disrupted as Storm Darragh hits UK". BBC News. BBC. 7 December 2024. Retrieved 7 December 2024.-
-"Two men killed by falling trees as Storm Darragh rages". BBC News. BBC. 7 December 2024. Retrieved 7 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Murder of Sara Sharif Urfan Sharif, 43, and Beinash Batool, 30, the father and stepmother of Sara Sharif, are sentenced at the Old Bailey for 10-year-old Sara Sharif's murder. Sharif receives a minimum term of 40 years, while Batool is given 33 years, with Justice Cavanagh describing their crimes as "a campaign of torture" in which "the degree of cruelty is almost inconceivable". The girl's uncle, Faisal Malik, 29, is imprisoned for 16 years.

Data.event_text: In Plymouth, a man is taken to hospital after being shot in the chest by an air rifle.

links.text: -"Man in hospital after being 'shot to the chest by air rifle'". BBC News. 17 December 2024. Retrieved 17 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Office for National Statistics indicates average pay increased at an annual rate of 5.2% between August and October 2024, the first increase for a year, and larger than expected.

links.text: -Edser, Nick (17 December 2024). "Pay growth jumps for first time in more than a year". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 17 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Train managers at Avanti West Coast vote to take strike action on New Year's Eve, 2 January, and every Sunday from 12 January until May after rejecting a deal aimed at resolving a dispute over rest day working.

links.text: -"Avanti West Coast staff to strike on New Year's Eve". Sky News. 17 December 2024. Retrieved 18 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Office for National Statistics data indicates UK inflation rose to 2.6% in November, the second consecutive monthly increase.

links.text: -Hooker, Lucy (18 December 2024). "UK inflation rate rises for second month in a row". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Deputy assistant commissioner Vicki Evans, senior national co-ordinator for Counter Terrorism Policing, warns that the UK faces a "smouldering" terror threat level with children as young as ten accessing extreme online material.

links.text: -Sandford, Daniel; Davies, Maia; Khalil, Hafsa (18 December 2024). "Threat against UK 'smouldering', top counter terror officer warns". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces plans to recruit hundreds of driving instructors to deal with a backlog of people waiting to take driving tests.

links.text: -Howard, Jacqueline; Davies, Maia (18 December 2024). "Driving tests: Hundreds of examiners to be recruited to cut wait times". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England votes to hold the UK interest rate at 4.75%, they say because the economy is performing worse than expected following the autumn budget.

links.text: -Jordan, Dearbail (19 December 2024). "UK interest rates held at 4.75%". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Ofwat announces that water bills in England and Wales are to increase over the next five years, starting with an average rise of £86 per year from April 2025.

links.text: -Espiner, Tom; Smith, Oliver (19 December 2024). "Water bills to rise by £86 on average next year, Ofwat says". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 19 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Peter Mandelson is appointed as the next UK ambassador to the United States.

links.text: -Wright, Ben; Pike, Joe; Francis, Sam (19 December 2024). "Labour veteran Peter Mandelson says US ambassador job an 'honour'". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 20 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Office for National Statistics figures indicate UK retail sales increased by 0.2% in November, less than the 0.5% forecast by economists.

links.text: -Makortoff, Kalyeena (20 December 2024). "Retail sales in Great Britain weaker than expected despite early Black Friday deals". The Guardian. Retrieved 20 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Office for National Statistics data indicates government borrowing was at its lowest for three years in November, with government debt at £11.2bn.

links.text: -Espiner, Tom (20 December 2024). "Government borrowing lower than expected in November". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 20 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The final edition of The Zoe Ball Breakfast Show is broadcast, with Zoe Ball stepping down as presenter of the Radio 2 morning show.

links.text: -"Zoe Ball in tears at son Woody's last show message". BBC News. BBC. 20 December 2024. Retrieved 20 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Wham!'s "Last Christmas" becomes Christmas number one for the second consecutive year, beating songs by Mariah Carey, Gracie Abrams, Tom Grennan and Ariana Grande.

links.text: -Savage, Mark (20 December 2024). "Wham's Last Christmas is the Christmas number one for a second consecutive year". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 20 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Wildlife TV presenter Chris Packham and former Green Party MP Caroline Lucas quit as president and vice-president of the RSPCA, in response to alleged animal cruelty at some of the charity's approved list of abattoirs.

links.text: -"Packham quits RSPCA over abattoir cruelty claims". BBC News. BBC. 21 December 2024. Retrieved 21 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Strong winds cause travel disruption for parts of the UK, as millions of people travel ahead of Christmas. Gusts of up to 82 mph are reported, with yellow weather warnings in place for Scotland, and much of Northern Ireland and northern England.

links.text: -"Strong winds disrupt Christmas getaway travel". BBC News. BBC. 21 December 2024. Retrieved 21 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Strong winds continue to cause disruption in parts of the UK, with Heathrow Airport cancelling around 100 flights.

links.text: -Wright, George; Binley, Alex (21 December 2024). "Christmas travel hit by high winds weather warning as Heathrow Airport cancels 100 flights". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: A BBC News investigation discovers that a Church of England priest at the centre of a sexual abuse case was twice reappointed to a senior role during Archbishop of York Stephen Cottrell's time as Bishop of Chelmsford. In response, Cottrell says he regrets the handling of the incident.

links.text: -Swann, Steve; Farley, Harry (22 December 2024). "Archbishop of York 'regrets' that abuse scandal priest David Tudor was reappointed twice". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 22 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Revised Office for National Statistics data shows economic growth was at 0% between July and September.

links.text: -Meierhans, Jennifer (23 December 2024). "UK economy had zero growth between July and September". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: A number of Morrisons stores have been beset with technical problems regarding discounts and deliveries.

links.text: -Rahman-Jones, Imran (23 December 2024). "Morrisons customers say Christmas deliveries and discounts down". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Chocolate manufacturer Cadbury is stripped of its Royal Warrant of Appointment after being included on the list of Appointments since 1854.

links.text: -Khan, Shehnaz (23 December 2024). "Cadbury dropped from royal warrant list after 170 years". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 23 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Two NHS hospitals in London are reported to be trialling artificial intelligence (AI) in order to detect signs of type 2 diabetes in patients.

links.text: -"Hospitals trial AI to spot type 2 diabetes risk". BBC News. 24 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that the UK motor industry is being consulted on how the phasing out of petrol and diesel engines by 2030 would work.

links.text: -"Car industry consulted over how to phase out petrol and diesel cars by 2030". BBC News. 24 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office forecasts mild and dry weather for Christmas Day throughout much of the UK.

links.text: -"UK weather: Christmas forecasted to be mild for most". BBC News. 24 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Off Dunkirk on the north coast of France, French authorities rescue 30 people from a small boat, whilst allowing those wishing to cross the Channel to England, to continue into British waters to be taken into the custody of British authorities.

links.text: -"France rescues over 100 migrants from Channel, capping deadly year for crossings". RFI. 26 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: A man is arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after four people were injured when they were hit by a car being driven on the wrong side of the road in Shaftesbury Avenue, central London.

links.text: -"Man arrested after four pedestrians injured in London crash". BBC News. 25 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: King Charles III delivers the Royal Christmas Message from London's Fitzrovia Chapel, where he praises health workers and calls for unity following the summer riots.

links.text: -"King praises health workers and calls for unity after riots". BBC News. 25 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Archbishop of York Stephen Cottrell delivers a Christmas message in place of the Archbishop of Canterbury, doing so as he prepares to assume acting charge of the Church of England.

links.text: -"Archbishop of York's Christmas sermon 'empty words', Bishop says". BBC News. 25 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 26 December  Data collected by MRI Software indicates a 4% decrease in the number of Boxing Day shoppers compared to the same day in 2023.

links.text: -"Boxing Day sales: High Street suffers as shoppers stay home". BBC News. 26 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The Prime Minister pays tribute to Nick Starmer, his younger brother who died from cancer the previous day. Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch expresses her condolences.

links.text: -"Starmer pays tribute to brother who died on Boxing Day". BBC News. 27 December 2024. Retrieved 27 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Flights to and from some of the UK's major airports, including Gatwick and Manchester, are disrupted due to fog.

links.text: -Vock, Ido; Rich, Ben (27 December 2024). "Flights at Manchester Airport and Gatwick Airport disrupted by fog". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 27 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Former Conservative Justice Secretary David Gauke, who is leading a review into sentencing and prison overcrowding, calls for greater use of open prisons in order to ease the pressure on closed category prisons.

links.text: -Comerford, Ruth (27 December 2024). "Make more use of open prisons, former minister David Gauke says". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 27 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: A man is charged with four counts of attempted murder and remanded in custody over an incident involving a car in London on Christmas Day.

links.text: -Lindsay, Anna (27 December 2024). "Soho: Man charged after car driven into people on Christmas Day". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 27 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 28 December  Fog continues to disrupt flights at UK airports.

links.text: -Khalil, Hafsa; Rizzini, Elizabeth (28 December 2024). "Disruption to UK flights continue as fog persists". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 28 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Weather warnings for rain, snow, and winds of up to 70 mph are issued for parts of the UK on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day.

links.text: -"Warnings of snow, wind and rain across the UK for New Year". BBC News. 29 December 2024. Retrieved 29 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Fog continues to disrupt flights to and from Gatwick Airport, doing so for a third consecutive day.

links.text: -Khalil, Hafsa (29 December 2024). "Fog continues to cause disruption at Gatwick Airport". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 29 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: The King and the Prime Minister pay tribute to Jimmy Carter, following the former US president's death at the age of 100.

links.text: -"Jimmy Carter: King and PM honour former US president after his death aged 100". The Standard. 30 December 2024. Retrieved 30 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Edinburgh's Hogmanay celebrations are cancelled amid weather warnings for heavy rain, high winds and snow over the New Year.

links.text: -Khalil, Hafsa; Cursino, Malu; Rizzini, Elizabeth; Bett, Darren (30 December 2024). "Hogmanay celebrations cancelled as UK-wide weather warnings take hold". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 30 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: Authorities in Argentina announce that five people have been charged in connection with the death of One Direction singer Liam Payne.

links.text: -Mercer, David; Buschschlüter, Vanessa (30 December 2024). "Liam Payne: Five charged in connection with singer's death". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 30 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 2025 New Year Honours Those recognised in the New Year Honours include Stephen Fry, Gareth Southgate, Sadiq Khan and Andy Street, who receive knighthoods, Emily Thornberry (DBE), Sarah Lancashire (CBE) and Keely Hodgkinson (MBE).

links.text: -Dean, Grace; Sandeman, George (30 December 2024). "New Year Honours: Gareth Southgate, Stephen Fry and Olympians on list". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 30 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 31 December  The death is announced of BBC Radio 2 presenter Johnnie Walker at the age of 79.

links.text: -Martin, Roy (31 December 2024). "BBC radio presenter Johnnie Walker has died at the age of 79". Radio Today. Retrieved 31 December 2024.-
